name: Los Angeles
intro_vibe: A network of micro-cities connected by freeways, ambition, and tacos.

general_info.description: Los Angeles is not a single city; it is a massive collection of distinct neighborhoods (micro-cities) separated by traffic. From the grit of Hollywood to the zen of Malibu and the hipster hills of Silver Lake. It is a city defined by its diversity, its car culture, and its creative energy. Don't try to 'see it all'—pick a neighborhood and live in it.

etiquette_tips: The Distance Reality: Distance is psychological, not geographic. 5km can take 45 minutes. Locals measure distance in 'time', not miles. 'It's close' means it is close *right now*.
Friendly but Shallow: People will compliment your shoes, ask where you're from, and say 'we should hang out'. This is politeness, not a commitment. Enjoy the warmth, but don't over-interpret it.
Casual is a Code: Flip-flops and athleisure are normal everywhere, but don't mistake 'casual' for 'sloppy'. In LA, looking relaxed is a form of social status. You can wear jeans to a $100 dinner.
The Car Shield: The car is personal space. People do not make eye contact at lights. They sing, make calls, and exist in solitude. Honking is rare and aggressive.
Dining Rhythm: Dinner is at 8pm. Reservations are essential. Dietary restrictions (Vegan, Gluten-Free, Keto) are accommodated everywhere without question—it is part of the infrastructure.
Tipping Landscape: 18-20% is standard. But also: Valets expect $2-5. Bartenders get $1-2 per drink. Hair and beauty services expect 20%.
Parking Signs are Hostile: Read the sign. Then read the second sign. Red curb = No Parking. Yellow = Commercial Loading. White = Passenger Loading. Street cleaning days = guaranteed ticket.

essential_phrases.phonetic: The four-oh-five (Always add 'The' before freeway names)

neighborhoods.name: Silver Lake & Echo Park
neighborhoods.description: The hills of East LA. Vintage stores, independent coffee shops, steep staircases, and a very localized community feel. It’s where the 'cool' crowd actually lives.

neighborhoods.name: Santa Monica
neighborhoods.description: The polished, walkable beach city. Great for first-timers and families. It feels safe and manicured, unlike its neighbor Venice. The Main Street area offers a more local vibe than the Pier.

neighborhoods.name: West Hollywood (WeHo)
neighborhoods.description: The party center. Legendary rock clubs on the Sunset Strip and the vibrant LGBTQ+ district on Santa Monica Blvd. High energy, very walkable, and historically significant.

neighborhoods.name: Arts District (DTLA)
neighborhoods.description: Converted warehouses filled with breweries, galleries, and high-end dining. Note: DTLA is fragmented. One block is trendy, the next (Skid Row) is a humanitarian crisis. Move intentionally.

logistics.title: Local Survival Tips
details: The Uber Strategy: Don't wait until you leave the venue to call a car. Call it 10-15 minutes early. Distances are long and drivers are far away.
Sunsets: The sun sets over the ocean. Plan your day to end facing West (Santa Monica/Malibu) for the view, but remember traffic heading West at 5pm is a nightmare.
Homelessness: Visible homelessness is a reality of daily life here. Most people are non-confrontational. Do not engage, do not stare, do not film. Just move on calmly.
Jaywalking: Recently decriminalized, but drivers are not used to it. Cars will not stop for you outside of crosswalks.

logistics.title: Getting Around
logistics.summary: You probably need a car. Public transit is patchy.
details: Car Rental: Essential if you want to see Malibu, hiking trails, or multiple neighborhoods. The car is your passport to the city.
Public Transit Reality: The Metro exists (Expo Line is good for Downtown -> Beach), but it is patchy and inconsistent. Locals with cars rarely use it. Late night service is sparse.
Uber/Lyft: Viable for nights out, but expensive as a primary mode of transport due to the sheer size of the city.
Walking: Only possible WITHIN neighborhoods (e.g., walking around Silver Lake). You cannot walk BETWEEN neighborhoods.

logistics.title: Parking Skills
logistics.summary: Parking is a bloodsport. Know the curb colors.
details: Red Curb: Absolute No Parking. You will be towed.
Yellow Curb: Commercial loading only (usually 7am-6pm). You can park here briefly after hours (check signs).
White Curb: Passenger loading only. 5 minutes max. Driver must stay in car.
Street Cleaning: Check the signs. If it says 'No Parking Tuesday 10am-12pm', they will ticket you at 10:01am.

must_eat.description: LA is arguably the best Mexican food city in the world. Know the difference: 'Taco Trucks' are for speed, street energy, and late nights (Al Pastor spit-roasted on the sidewalk). 'Taquerías' are for sit-down regional specialties like Oaxacan Mole or Yucatecan Cochinita Pibil. Do not limit yourself to just tacos.

K-Town is a city within a city. K-BBQ is not just a meal; it is a 2-hour social event. Meat is grilled at your table, accompanied by endless 'banchan' (side dishes). It is loud, smoky, and communal. Leaving smelling like grilled meat is a badge of honor.

The California classic. Order a 'Double-Double Animal Style' (grilled onions + extra sauce). It is fast food, but the ingredients are never frozen and chopped fresh daily. The menu is simple for a reason.

LA has the highest Japanese population in the US. The best sushi is often found in unassuming strip malls in the Valley or West LA, not just flashy noble places. The fish quality is universally high, from Omakase bars to casual hand-roll counters.

Health is a flavor profile here. Expect to find Cold-Pressed Juice, Açaí Bowls, and 'Adaptogenic Smoothies' on every corner. It’s not a diet; it’s a lifestyle. Breakfast often looks like a $14 smoothie rather than a pastry.

A distinct LA morning ritual, often driven by Cambodian-American families who own the majority of independent shops. These pink-box donut shops are everywhere, open early (or 24/7), cheap, and unpretentious. The 'Old Fashioned' or 'Apple Fritter' are staples.
A historic food hall in Downtown since 1917. It brings together the city's diversity under one roof: pupusas, currywurst, tacos, and trendy egg sandwiches. It is crowded, loud, and iconic.

items.description: Do not confuse this with Santa Monica. Venice is the gritty, artistic, chaotic soul of the coast. Walk the Boardwalk to see Muscle Beach, street performers, skaters, and the sheer weirdness of LA on display. It is raw and unapologetic.

LA is a city meant to be seen from a car. Driving the winding ridges of Mulholland offers spectacular views of the LA Basin on one side and the San Fernando Valley on the other. Stop at the scenic overlooks at sunset.

The best vantage point in the city. You get a direct line of sight to the Hollywood Sign and a panoramic view of the grid below. It is a stunning Art Deco monument to public science. Go on a weekday to survive the parking.

Vintage shopping is a sport here. The massive Rose Bowl Flea Market (monthly) or the weekly Melrose Trading Post are where locals build their 'casual' aesthetic. It’s about hunting for unique denim, furniture, and art.

The 'social hike'. Great city views, lots of dogs, and a high chance of a celebrity sighting (or at least an influencer filming a workout). Wear your best matching workout set; this is a place to be seen.

A modernist masterpiece by Richard Meier perched on a hilltop. It offers world-class art, stunning architecture, and white travertine gardens. The tram ride up sets the tone: you are leaving the city noise behind.

The most authentic studio tour. Unlike theme parks, this takes you into working soundstages and backlots where 'Friends', 'Gilmore Girls', and Batman movies were actually filmed. Essential for film history fans.

affiliate_products.title: US Travel Adapter (Type A/B)
affiliate_products.reason: US plugs have two flat pins. If you're from Europe, you need an adapter.

affiliate_products.title: Sunscreen SPF 50
affiliate_products.reason: The California sun is strong, even when it feels cool. Wear it driving, hiking, and walking.

affiliate_products.title: Hiking Water Bottle
affiliate_products.reason: LA is dry and hot. You need water constantly, especially if you hike Runyon or Griffith.
